B00005JMEW|5.0|With Kill Bill, you have a line drawn, those who love it and those who hate it. Either you like it for it's cool action, sharp and witty dialogue, creative and fun characters, and well choreographed style and well shot cinematography. Or, you hated it for it's over the top violence, simple story, and interesting casting. Either way, this is one well done film. Now, there is no doubt that Tarantino is one of modern times best filmmakers. He is a noncomforist filmmaker of sorts, who still sides on a more independent note than trying to put out the Next Big Thing. And Kill Bill is his message of this: rather than trying to create a pop culture flick that will make tons of bucks, he's created something he can enjoy. In other words, this is Tarantino's fanboy film.  <br /> <br />The film itself is qute simple. A former assassin goes on a rampage of revenge to kill the man who took away the life she wanted to have. But in retrospect, the film is more about it's characters than what they do. Uma Thurmans 'Bride' is not just a one dimensional killing machine. She's a woman who lost her baby. An ex-assassin who just may be the world's deadliest woman. She's someone who you could be good friends with, as long as you don't get on her bad side. While most of the other characters aren't nearly as well developed, they do at least have interesting enough backstories to them. And, at the very least they are interesting.  <br /> <br />One other thing you know you can get from a Tarantino film is great writing, and thats no less true here. The film sparkles with great dialogue. Whether it's Uma's narration (which are very well voiced) or the exchanges and banter between friend's and foe (Sonny Chiba's scene being one of my favorites), there is a bounty of great lines here. Yes, some of it seems a bit out of place, but the style is just so darn cool, you can't help but go along with it. <br /> <br />As for the action, it's some of the bloodiest to have graced the screen in a while, but it's also quite stylish. The choreography is well done and the fights are creative, ranging from teenage girl with a chained and spiked ball (resembling something out of an anime) to a fight in a homemmakers suburban house, the battles are entertaining and spark the imagination.  <br /> <br />Now, I will say, this movie isn't for everyone. Yes, it is overly violent. Yes, it does have an unusual style that is mostly in service of Tarantino's own fandom. But, the film is cool, stylish, and one great time. And, if you like Quentin's previous works, you're in for a treat, because this is one of his best to date. Now stop reading this, and go get this movie....now!
B000ASDFJU|1.0|So this is basically a giant slap in the face for anybody who went out and bought all the seasons separately, extremely crappy packaging and all. <br />Gee, thanks HBO.  Last time I'll be purchasing anything from you. <br />Signed, <br />One bitter freaking consumer.
B00005JMUA|5.0|The first Kill Bill was a pure delight. At the end, one wondered where the series would go next. I was surprised to find that the second volume was different in many ways from the first. The over the top and modernly stylized fights from the first film were replaced by old fashioned, chinese oriented action. There is also a much more western feel to the film. Overall, it just had a completely different feel, yet, it didn't betray it's first half. The characters were still faithful to themselves from the first go around, and the dialogue didn't seem to change much in tone.  <br /> <br />This volume picks up right where the first one ends. The Bride is off to finish off the last of those who betrayed her, with it all ending with Bill. The story doesn't sway in the least, and in fact, it seems to be a bit simpler this time around. There are a few more twists in this one, but nothing too shocking. And of course, we finally learn the Brides true name, as well as we finally get to see the face of Bill.  <br /> <br />It is debatable which of the two is actually the better film, but that depends on what it is you like more. This film replaces the modern, city-like environments with more western like environments: open desert, vista backgrounds, and mexican countryside. It certainly does give the movie a different feel, but this works for the better. The series is diversified to a greater extent by showing the multifaceted personalities of the many characters. We get a good feel for who Bud is, and to a greater extent, Bill. Like the first movie, the characters are well told, not just through their dialogue, but through their actions and surroundings.  <br /> <br />The strong point, aside from character, is once again the writing. One of the best chunks of lines from any Tarantino film is in this movie, and it's about Superman nonetheless (you'll know what I mean when you see it). Elle, who was a so-so character in the first film, is much more fleshed out in this one. She takes on a much more despised role here (which is a good thing), and therefore, become a character we're much more willing to see. Pai Mei is also one of the best characters to come around in years, with his old-chinese-man look and foul mouth. Overall, the characters of this film are just generally more interesting, except for Go-go, who still holds a special place in this fans heart.  <br /> <br />One thing that is debatable is whether or not the tone of the film, which changed dramatically, is a good thing or a bad thing. Some would say that the tone of this film is much better, but I for one think that it moved a little too slow. The first film moved with lightning pace, never taking a moment to stop and rest. This film however, takes its time, which isn't necessarily a bad thing, it's just a little less enthusiastic than the first one. <br /> <br />Just as in the first volume, V2 does an excellent job of finishing the series up. It doesn't betray it's characters or feel, while still being different enough to be a film on it's own right. It's just as stylish, just as well written, and simply put, a film that is just as good, maybe even better, than the first.

B00000K31V|5.0|When I unearthed a bargain price VHS copy of \\"eXistenZ\\" I had no recollection of having even heard of the film. At that price and with a cast that included Sarah Polley, Jennifer Jason Leigh, and Ian Holm I figured, why not experiment? Unlike most of my video experiments I fell immediately into the story and really enjoyed the film. It is easy to watch and while Polley and Holm have small parts, Leigh is on screen for almost the entire film. Which is probably why she elected to do this instead of \\"Eyes Wide Shut\\". Her co-star is Jude Law in what I would rate his all-time best performance.    Although I was very impressed I don't recommend \\"eXistenZ\\" for everyone. It could be described as an anti-\\"Matrix\\". Not in an intentional sense since they were being made at the same time, but rather in their respective target audiences. So if you seek it out because you really liked \\"The Matrix\\", you may be disappointed.    It has a fairly narrow target audience and because of this it was not aggressively distributed in the U.S. and did much better in Europe. Generally those who really connected to \\"The Matrix\\" will find it insufficiently manipulative (requiring too much viewer self-analysis and participation) while those who hated \\"The Matrix\\" will hate it for being too manipulative. So if you found \\"Matrix\\" generally intriguing but did not go ga-gah over it, you should make it a point to check out \\"eXistenZ\\".    It is not really sci-fi or action adventure but a psychological thriller (just as \\"The Hole\\" is not a horror film but a psychological thriller). It places Kurt Vonnegut's theme \\"you are what you pretend to be so be careful what you pretend to be\\" into an allegorical tale of shifting reality. Do we ever actually exercise free will? Does escaping from reality contribute to reality getting worse, in actuality or in our perception? You are meant to internalize this theme and to ask yourself these questions.    My only real complaint is that the final twist (unlike the earlier twists) does not click into place when you first see it nor later as you work backwards to find clues and foreshadowing elements that support this element. Without these the twist is silly and unnecessary. While it does not ruin all that has gone before it seems like just a lame attempt to prepare the way for a sequel.     Then again, what do I know? I'm only a child.
B000000OQF|5.0|Guns N' Roses...definitely one of the better bands of the 80's. I mean how many bands went this far with their music back in that decade? Slash, Axl, Izzy, Duff, and Steve all worked their asses off when they created this, and I dont think it could've gotten much better. From the opening riff to 'Welcome to the Jungle' to the closing lines \\"all I wanted is for you to know that I care\\" in 'Rocket Queen' this album holds strong throughout. If anybody thinks that this is hairband then I've got news for you, they were far, far, FAR from a hairband. A perfect example of a hairmetal act would be Bon Jovi (Blowme), as they never took pride in their work, relied solely on image,  and only cared about money, they were the Good Charlotte of the 80's. Guns N' Roses (especially Slash) loved to make music, I think that should be obvious for anyone. This album revived hard rock at a time when the genre had hit rock bottom thanks to bands like Poison, and if there is any other album from the 80's that everyone should have, this is it with the addition of Metallicas '...And Justice for All'. Axl Roses voice may have been high, but it fit the band and it was definitely unique at the time. Slash was the main man along with Dave Mustaine in the guitar world from '87 - '93, keep in mind that Eddie Van Halen kinda lost his edge by this time thanks to Hagar (damn you Sammy). Izzy had a great rhythem section to match Slash's brilliant solos and single note melodies. Duff McKagens basslines were great to provide a stable backbone for G N' R. Steve Adler has to be the most underrated drummer of all time, he had fast and POUNDING drum rhythems, he actually sounded like a very creative version of Lars Ulrich. Right, the best songs here are 'Welcome to The Jungle' (obviously), 'Its So Easy', 'Paradise City', 'My Michelle', and 'Sweet Child O' Mine' (again, obviously). If you like hard rock, rock in general, or just music than you MUST have this, it is an essential album for the ages.

0307276902|5.0|A Million Little Pieces is a gripping account of the 6 weeks James Frey spent in a treatment center in Minnesota for his addiction to alcohol and other drugs.  The abuse of drugs can really ruin the body.  There is a very descriptive part in the book where Frey describes the painful experience he endured having several root canals done without anethesia to repair his damaged teeth.  The abuse of drugs can also damage the relationship a person has with their family.  One of the more moving parts of this book is where Frey confronts his parents in counseling to tell them about his drug use and drug dealing.<br /><br />They are heartbroken to hear about all the bad things their son has done, and they become closer as a result of his confession. This is a bit predictable, but it is still really moving to read.  I also think that Frey is very brutally honest as he describes a constant craving for alcohol and drugs while in rehab.<br /><br />Every patient at the treatment center has a job to perform, and I really reading how Frey's jobs changed while he was there.  He cleaned toilets in the beginning, and then he switched to making coffee.  He finally became a greeter in his last days.  Frey spends a lot of time describes the friendships he made while in the treatment center.  Having other people around him who were struggling with the same addictions  helped James get better.  I thought it was interesting that one of the patients and one of James' friends at the rehab center was a judge.  I really enjoyed reading about his friendship with a crime boss named Leonard who kept him in the program.  James Frey's romantic relationship with a woman  named Lilly who suffered from sexual and drug abuse was very sweet.<br /><br />I think the message of A Million Little Pieces is that a person can overcome their addiction to alcohol and drugs if they have  people who can support them, and if they are willing and determined enough.  I enjoyed reading this book very much.
0060730552|5.0|This is a true story of a mountain expedition in the Andes where two British partners take risks acceptable to experienced and fit climbers. But here they draw a spectacularly bad hand - first with Joe having a terrible bone crunching accident that leaves him scarcely able to move, and then with rapidly deteriorating weather. Partner Simon attempts the impossible and begins an inventive, courageous one-man rescue operation, but half way down the mountain he is forced to make a ghastly choice: stay roped to Joe and both will perish, or cut the rope and make a desperate bid to reach the bottom.<br /><br />Simon chooses the latter, and the result is horrifying: with Joe plunging into a deep crevasse with no way of climbing up the sheer ice.<br /><br />But of course this memoir is written by Joe so we know that somehow, against all odds, our author will also get himself to safety. How he does so, and how he skirts around the very edges of death provides the book with its extremely powerful human resonance.<br /><br />I read this after seeing the excellent movie, and Joe's reflections, at the end of this book about the experience of helping make the film and reliving the horror (he and Simon are played by actors in wide shot, but the climbers provided all the close-up technical shots)- provides additional and unexpected depth and humanity.<br /><br />There's another reviewer below who was bored by this book. They must have been having a really bad day because Joe's writing takes you right into the heart of his ordeal. This is a stunning story. Five stars aren't enough.

1573223026|5.0|One of the many things I enjoy about Nick Hornby's books is his ability to take people I probably would either not like or notice and turn them into intriguing characters. I mean I've probably passed a number of Rob Fleming's of HIGH FIDELITY fame in various book and music stores in my lifetime, but apart from a short conversation I know nothing about them. In the hands of Nick Hornby, the Rob Flemings of the world become sympathetic characters we can all relate to because we either are Rob Fleming or we known a Rob Fleming. For the Will Lightman's of the world, introduced in ABOUT A BOY, I usually think \\"get a job and a life like everyone else\\" but when a writer like Nick Hornby finds a Will Lightman, he becomes a lovable bloke instead of a pathetic loser and we find ourselves rooting for him. Hornby uses these same skills but in a different manner in his latest work LONG WAY DOWN.<br /><br />In this novel, we meet four people who are atop a building on New Year's Eve, ready to end it all. We meet Martin, a former television star who has been jailed for sex with an underage girl; Maureen, a mother of a severely disabled child; Jess, a lost young woman who is the daughter of a political leader; and JJ, and American expatriate and wannabee rock star. None of them actually take the leap and a rather odd community develops between the four. While at times it seem somewhat implausible, and in the hands of a less skilled writer would probably be nothing but outlandish, somehow the novel seems to work and we find ourselves believing in the small world of these four people.<br /><br />The book is told from a first person point of view with all four characters having separate chapters. Hornby does a good job at creating distinct voices for the characters so we're never confused as to who is doing the narrating. He moves the book along rather well too. One character begins telling the story, then another picks it up. We don't get too many repeats of action or the four characters telling the same event. It's almost as if all four characters are in separate rooms. We walk in one room and one is speaking, then we leave and go to another and pick up the story again. The same holds true for room three and four.<br /><br />My guess is that LONG WAY DOWN will become a film. I would think it could make a good movie, but like HIGH FIDELITY and ABOUT A BOY, it could loose a bit of its edge. As a book we stay with each character and I'm not sure how that could be recreated on film, so read the book just in case it becomes a film.aracters telling the same event. It's almost as if all four characters are in separate rooms. We walk in one room and one is speaking, then we leave and go to another and pick up the story again. The same holds true for room three and four.  <br /> <br />My guess is that LONG WAY DOWN will become a film. I would think it could make a good movie, but like HIGH FIDELITY and ABOUT A BOY, it could loose a bit of its edge. As a book we stay with each character and I'm not sure how that could be recreated on film, so read the book just in case it becomes a film.  <br />

B000003C5C|4.0|Death were never the fastest metal band, nor were they the most brutal, but the incredible music that they made was head and shoulders above the other death metal bands at the time for one special reason: their music had heart. i first heard Death on the At Death's Door compilation; and their song (\\"Open Casket\\") stood out so strongly among all the other featured bands on that collection. their was a unique sense of conviction in Death that is so simple: songs first, speed second. sure these tunes are fast...but it's never one million blast beats a minute just for the sake of being fast and furious. the tunes speak for themselves and are the testament of the killer songwriting of Chuck Schuldiner. his craft for melding memorable thrashy riffs combined with his mid-range throaty growl (which always reminded me a bit of Obituary's singer) is truly second to none. and no one can write a review of Death without mentioning the fantastic solo ability of Chuck. his grasp of melodic phrasing within these frames of brutal intensity is worthy of much praise. you could almost say that it's one of the biggest assets of Death's metal...something that further sets them as the band to believe in and the band to inspire greatness!

0060977493|5.0|My sister had been telling me to read this book for a long time and I just never got around to it. I wanted to, but I have to admit that the subject matter seemed pretty standard for an award-winning book: 'The God of Small Things' centers around a tragedy that rends a family apart and its lasting effects on the twins who were at the heart of it. But the truth is that there is little that is standard about Arundhati Roy's writing. She tells her story in a completely original narrative that puts you inside the heads of the young twins who drive the plot. You see the world through the slightly fantastic, exaggerated eyes of a child caught in very grown-up circumstances. I can see that some would criticize her style as \\"weird\\", but that is the whole beauty of it. Most children that I know see the world in a slightly off-kilter way (and I know for a fact that I did). That's just the nature of kids. The innocence of the perspective makes the events of the plot seem that much more disturbing and downright chilling. I was wrong to expect a by-the-numbers book when I picked this up. Ms. Roy's novel is very original and well written. Now if only she would write another fiction book!

B0006Q1ULQ|5.0|I've recently started reading Umberto Eco's Baudolino, a rambunctious tale of a thirteenth century opportunist. \\"The world condemns liars who do nothing but lie, even about the most trivial things, and it rewards poets, who lie only about the greatest things.\\"<br /><br />Although I'm only 120 pages into this 500 page novel, I'm engrossed by the weaving plots and rich characters. Baudolino is an Italian peasant with a gift for languages and a bald-faced liar who is adopted by an emperor as a boy and falls in love with the emperor's young bride as a teenager. He studies at the University of Paris in its first years, and befriends a wannabe poet and a moorish scholar, and the three of them are off now on worldly quests, befuddled by alcohol and \\"green honey\\".<br /><br />The thirteenth century was an influential time for so many elements of our modern society, seeing the usurpation of the church in Europe by the birth of the university, science, nationalism and capitalism, for all the good and bad that it all heralded. This book thus far does a great job of chronicling this from the perspective of someone entrenched in the middle of it all. It's great fun to compare our modern knowledge with that of a medieval persona.<br /><br />I'll let you know what I think when I'm done with it, but so far, I'd highly recommend Umberto Eco's Baudolino.

B0000AI44Q|5.0|The more I listen, the more I've come to believe \\"Greendale\\" is one of Neil's true masterpieces. At first, it seems like just another Crazy Horse album with the volume, distortion and anger turned way down. But, like a Steinbeck novel, its brilliance grows on you. For a Crazy Horse collaboration, there is an intimacy to these songs that I find thrilling. Without question their best work since \\"Ragged Glory\\". The feeling is one of sitting on a beat-up couch in a garage some lazy summer evening while Neil and the boys jam and tell you the story of small town dreams, both dashed and realized. \\"Carmichael\\" and \\"Grandpa's Interview\\" are nearly perfect both musically and lyrically; the beauty lies in a masterful balance of Ralph and Billy's propulsive rhythms and Neil's barely-restrained fuzzed guitar and seemingly stream-of-consciousness singing. The rest of the album is just as satisfying, especially the way-too-cool-for-words rockabilly anthem \\"Double EE\\" and the opening track \\"Falling from Above,\\" which so wonderfully sets the stage for the hour+ journey. A definite candidate as a desert island disc.  <br /> <br />

0385338686|4.0|The premise of this story is simple:  a young English lawyer has her fast-track career derailed in a spectacular way.  She stumbles into a new career and learns some hard but valuable lessons about life's tradeoffs.  Yes, it's true that some elements of the story are predictable, but readers of chick lit would be just a little disappointed if Mr. Right didn't turn up somewhere, right? And it does seem that our heroine's domestic IQ seems impossibly low for someone who graduated with honors from Cambridge.  But I found myself rooting for Samantha from the first page and sped through the book because I wanted to find out how she would manage to make lemonade from lemons.  This book is a fun, quick read that should appeal to fans of the Shopaholic series who appreciate SK's ability to create likable, quirky, and spunky heroines.

B000A3XYZA|5.0|Villegier presents Handels great opera Rodelinda in silent movie terms - characters are made up with white paint and lipstick; the costumes on the women are gorgeous 1920s and the acting is heavily stylized as in an old Gloria Swanson film. And it works!!! the stylized movements and emoting exactly fit Handels very stylized and formal composing. To top it off the singing is superb. Andreas Scholl in his operatic debut is astounding - \\"Dove Sei\\" is heart rendingly beautiful, the bravura arias are superb and the acting is heartfelt. As a matter of fact all of the singers are thoroughly in the Handel idiom and William Christie leads his great Orchestra of the Age of Enlightenment in a very dramatic performance. One of the best operatic DVDs I have ever seen.

B0000714B5|4.0|This is a beautiful film in many ways, probably none more so than in the way the director has interpreted Herman Hesse's novel of the same name. I see little point in regurgitating the essence of the plot as it really does nothing but detract from the purpose of the review.<br /><br />As with all works of art, in whatever media form it may be expressed, this is an interpretive statement of the author's original novel and as such it is an interpretation as much based on the audience it is geared up to as well as the film maker's. It may be legitimate for a critic to dispute the finer points of the interpretation or even  the philosophical or religious underpinnings but in this case, it seems to me that we miss the point.<br /><br />As a reader, I must confess to finding all of Hesse's work not as it would appear at first glance. Even Siddhartha, an apparently simple tale, is a much more complex and thought provoking text than it appears. Not being an expert in this area, I do not dare to present an exegis of the book which I will happily leave to more authoritative reviewers.<br /><br />To me the director has tried to tease out, as he sees them, the salient points of the text and has done so in a personal form as if the main character is the narrator. He tells the tale in a rather unfeeling way suggesting a sense of detatchment and objectivity, a device which is present throughout the movie and which in a way denies the need to try and deal with an emotional aspect. Siddhartha's inability to deny his emotions is sorely tested when his newly found son rejects him and runs away to the town. Further, his innate inability to recognise these passions and deal with them brings into sharp focus the imbalance in his character of being too objective, too clever, too logical. In a way the film seems to be taking more of a Zen approach throughout.<br /><br />There is abundant beauty throughtout this film. Not surprisingly the three central characters are very photogenic and beautiful and their surroundings are clear and beautiful too. The exposure of poverty and opulence to the camera gives everything an appearance of beauty including the poor and the holy men. This again allows the highlighting of the bad as feelings and inhumanity such as the travellers pushing away the young boy as he searches urgently for help for his mother.<br /><br />There is beauty too in the overall serenity of the movie which perhaps may have been an aim of the director.<br /><br />Ultimately, this movie can be interpreted too on many levels and in that it certainly follows the book. I found it to be engrossing and thought provoking and my only negative is the excessive echo on the voices.<br /><br />This is a must for anyone who wishes to take an introduction into Hesse's work before delving into the text. It is worth watching too as a sumptuous spectacle of filmmaking.and beautiful and their surroundings are clear and beautiful too. The exposure of poverty and opulence to the camera gives everything an appearance of beauty including the poor and the holy men. This again allows the highlighting of the bad as feelings and inhumanity such as the travellers pushing away the young boy as he searches urgently for help for his mother. <br /> <br />There is beauty too in the overall serenity of the movie which perhaps may have been an aim of the director. <br /> <br />Ultimately, this movie can be interpreted too on many levels and in that it certainly follows the book. I found it to be engrossing and thought provoking and my only negative is the excessive echo on the voices. <br /> <br />This is a must for anyone who wishes to take an introduction into Hesse's work before delving into the text. It is worth watching too as a sumptuous spectacle of filmmaking.

B000A78Z82|3.0|Some musicians get better with time. Some do not.  I cannot say for certain which category Devendra Banhart falls into.  However, I can say that his new album, \\"Cripple Crow,\\" released on September 15th, is disappointingly not at all like his past work. <br /> Sure, his voice still quivers and soars over a wide-range of notes, but this time the listener's relationship with him is different.  Before, sighs and imperfect execution made listeners feel as though they were Banhart's private audience for an impromptu concert put on for friends.  This time, the songs are perfected and sound professionally mixed.  There are no characteristic whispers of, \\"1, 2, 3, 4,\\" before each song.  We are no longer Devendra Banhart's close friends, but paid listeners of an impersonal and distant musician.   <br /> Banhart's recording attitude is not the only thing different in \\"Cripple Crow.\\"  This album trades his former casual, gypsy-influenced folk style with a folk style diluted with classic rock and Mexican folk music.  Indeed, it seems that every other song trades off sounding like a cheap cover of Bob Dylan or a Mexican serenade.  This album also breaks away from Banhart's former solo acoustic style with the addition of other artists and instruments.  It is mainly the collaborative aspect of this album that causes the loss of intimacy and Devendra Banhart-charm. <br /> The track, \\"I Feel Just Like a Child,\\" is so strongly reminiscent of Bob Dylan that it could really lose Banhart's original audience.  The better of the 22 songs on this album, namely \\"Heard Somebody Say,\\" \\"Inaniel,\\" \\"Hey Mama Wolf,\\" and a few others, suggest something of the old Banhart charm but are still obviously heavily `studioized.'  We are no longer out in the woods with Banhart-we are listening to a cold, hard disk in our rooms.   <br /> Contributing to the lack of the former outdoors-feel is the strange mix of lyric subjects.  On Banhart's earlier albums, the lyrics were most often concerned with insects,animals, and the outdoors; but on \\"Cripple Crow,\\" despite the misleading title, the songs range in subject matter from The Beatles to marrying little boys.  <br /> Still, it must be said that \\"Cripple Crow\\" has some redeeming qualities.  Banhart's intricate guitar work is still present and the introductions of new instruments (piano, horns, bass, and drums) are decent additions to a few songs.  There are also times when the background singers add a memorably catchy element to the songs, and the seven songs in Spanish are also interesting and worth listening to.    <br /> Of the 22 songs, I would consider 12 to be decent.  Original Devendra Banhart fans might be disappointed in the album as a whole, but these 12 tracks make \\"Cripple Crow\\" an important addition to a Devendra Banhart collection. \\"Cripple Crow\\" is certainly more accessible than Banhart's past albums to music listeners not accustomed to, or not fond of, his old style.  This album would also particularly appeal to those whose music collections consist of artists like Bob Dylan and Phish.
B00006LI4S|5.0|If you like Pink Floyd even a little you must watch this DVD.  Every song is lovingly arranged and performed.  I got goosebumps at least three different times. It is in 5.1 surround and in 16:9 ratio perfect for widescreen tv's and home theater enthusiasts.  Buy it now and enjoy!
B0009R1T7M|5.0|This summer was a great one for music with a large number of tours, the first ever Intonation Festival with two days of mostly excellent music, and the release of Sufjan Stevens' \\"Come On Feel the Illinoise\\" album.   <br /> In the Sufjan Stevens' tradition, layered and complex instrumentation and melodies are mixed with simplistic ones to create varying moods throughout \\"Come On Feel the Illinoise.\\"  And, as always, Stevens mixes mature lyrics with whimsical, humorous prose.  Despite continuing his classic style, Stevens does not fail to produce an entirely unique album.   <br />Dedicated to the state of Illinois, the album is the second installment in his plan to produce an album for each of the fifty United States.  This album includes songs written about Illinois' history, famous people, cities, small towns, and even a serial killer.  Most of the 22 songs on the album are titled with long and ridiculous names, such as \\"The Black Hawk War, Or, How To Demolish An Entire Civilization And Still Feel Good About Yourself In The Morning, Or, We Apologize For The Inconvenience But You're Going To Have To Leave Now, Or...\\" and \\"They Are Night Zombies!! They Are Neighbors!! They Have Come Back From The Dead!! Ahhhh!\\"  It is these eccentric songs coupled with somber songs such as \\"John Wayne Gacey Jr.\\" that make \\"Come On Feel the Illinoise\\" such a unique representation of the complexity of human emotions. <br />In contrast to the long title names, the songs vary in length from 19 seconds to almost seven minutes.  Some of the songs run into one anther and some are continuations of the previous tracks, clearly indicating that the album is meant to be listened to as a whole.  The album begins with an eclectic mix of banjos, vocal harmonies, piano, guitar, and drums, all of which are used on and off through the rest of the tracks.  The beginning tracks are upbeat and almost childish in attitude, however complex the musicianship is.  <br />Though a few of the tracks are writtenin the same key and they may sound very similar to a listener unaccustomed to Stevens' style, a closer listen reveals new ideas and complicated riffs that greatly contribute to the album as a whole.   <br />Soon the upbeat and carefree mood changes, however, and the album takes on a more serious tone.  \\"John Wayne Gacey Jr.\\" is an emotional song, recounting the horrors of Gacey's crime while showing him as a real man. Intensely respectful, Stevens' relates his own secrets and discretions to Gacey's in the lines \\"in my best behavior, I am just like him, look beneath the floorboards, for the secrets I have hid...\\"  <br />The rest of the album cycles between moods and ideas, each complimenting the other by providing contrast and complexity.  The album truly works best when listened to in order.   Never failing to implement elements of folk, jazz, and cinematic musical genres in a intricate layering of instrumentation and vocals, Sufjan Stevens produces an album that is a worthwhile addition to any collection.

B0000042H4|5.0|On LP these recordings were appealingly airy, but with incredible impact, placement of singers, and sonic bloom. On the original Decca CD masterings, they turned wiry and harsh. This was a shocking thing to do to the greatest Ring cycle, whatever one might say about Solti's high-voltage, take no prisoners conducting.<br /><br />Now the error has been corrected to a great degree. The latest remastering is much more listenable, less harsh and wiry. But we still have a ways to go. Perhaps in the future some new digital technology will bring back the beautiful sonics of the original Lps.

B000001XO3|4.0|I bought this live 1953 Ring cycle almost as soon as it came out, lured by the notable Clemens Krauss and a lineup of famous Wagnerian singers. The Amazon reviewer is right to call them stalwarts--there are flashes of brilliance in quite a few of the protrayals vocally--and the sound is good broadcast  mono for the period. Windgassen is seriously overparted as Siegfried, but he was the best anyone could do for a very long time after Melchor's retirement. Overall, this set gives a fair portrait of Bayreuth at its best using post-war singers.<br /><br />For all its virtues and incredibly cheap price, for me the real problem was in the orchestra.  I found Krauss sloppy too much of the time, and hiss tendency toward relaxed, lyrical phrasing bothered me when I wanted dramatic thrust. One doesn't expect perfection in live performances, of course, but I could not find many long stretch of conducting that equalled the greats and near-greats who have given us music from the Ring: Furtwangler, Karajan, Levine, Solti, Szell, Klemperer, etc. However, in his way Krauss does better than the brusque, rushed Karl Bohm in his live Ring cycle from Bayreuth twelve years later (on Philips). As Live cycles go, I found that I enjoyed neither this one nor the Bohm quite enough to call them great. I will stick with studio versions.<br /><br />P.S. March 2010 -- Looking back, I was too blase about Krauss's ring. Now that we have it in better sound from other labels -- particular in the total overhaul done by Andrew Rose of Pristine audio -- the vocal merits stand out, even if the orchestra's contribution still seems too sloppy and, thanks to backward placement, sonically muted.

B000001G53|5.0|Some disappointed reviewers have piled on to this recording, but I feel that it is unsurpassed among modern performances on disc. Karajan had conducted a live Parsifal from the Vienna State Opera (on BMG) that has the incomparable Hans Hotter as Gurnemanz and Christa Ludwig singing Kundry in Act 2 magnificently (strangely, Karajan asked for two Kundrys, each given her own act).<br /><br />Despite those advantages in Vienna, Karajan grew musically with this opera and here gives a performance of astounding depth and virtuosity. The orchestral playing is miles ahead of that achieved in the pit by Knappertsbusch in his various live performances from Bayreuth, and the digital sound, though not perfect, is very good for the Eighties.<br /><br />Kurt Moll sings with authority as Gurnemanz, besides his rolling deep bass, there is a feeling of enormous sorrow mixed with spiritual gravitas. Only Hotter exceeds him on CD. For many listeners the Kundry of Dunja Vejkovic will be too Slavic--at loud volume the voice turns shrill and squawky--but dramatically she is fierce with anguish when needed. Don't expect eroticism in Act 2, however.<br /><br />Which brings us to Peter Hofmann as Parsifal. This is not a long role vocally, and by no means does he spoil the set. His career was a flash in the pan, and his Tristan for Bernstein is a disaster despite the fact that his Siegmund for Boulez in the famous Chereau production had been a triumph. Here he is in as good form as he ever achieved. To his credit Hofmann is intense and dramatically believable, but the role puts vocal strains on him, and it shows. I have seen raves at Amazon for Wagner singing that is equally strained, but I can't paper over the fact that Hofmann is underpowered in the final Grail scene, a considerable drawback.<br /><br />In the end, Karajan's conducting is the element that sweeps this Parsifal to the heights. His vision is so musical, virtuosic, and passionate that I cannot understand any rating but the highest.est.
6301744160|3.0|On one hand, this movie is absolutely incredible.  The special effects, suspense, and adventuristic elements are very well done and very engaging.  In general, it's definitely entertaining and fun to sit back and just allow to take you along, like the ship in the bloodstream.  It also throws random thoughts about religion and philosophy out in a way that should at least be appreciated for trying to cater to an intellectual audience, I suppose...<br /><br />On the other hand, it has terrible dialog, pretty bad acting, one-dimensional characters, is so caught up in the Cold War, and fails to make those philosophical shout-outs mean anything.<br /><br />Thus, while we're thrown from one aspect of pretty well researched anatomy to another, it can take your breath away two ways: by dazzling with visuals, and by derisive laughter at the total inanity of the writing.  It's just too silly to take seriously, and yet it doesn't seem to have been created to be comedic but awe-inspiring.<br /><br />Modern day audiences, as well, will get a good hearty chuckle at the little Intelligent Design situation.  Good to know we haven't gotten any further, really, in our intelligence than when we were scared to death of Russian saboteurs.<br /><br />--PolarisDiB
B000A0GP4K|4.0|This film follows Dylan up until 1966, and it is not THE story of Bob Dylan, so much as A story of Bob Dylan. Those familiar with the history might get a little antsy in places, and at first I was a little frustrated that we find ourselves focusing on the young Dylan most people have in their heads already, instead of the older Dylan who seems the more interesting subject, if only because he's been less exposed. The film tells, in a way, why Dylan probably didn't want to touch on that, why he changed and retreated from view, and the last half-hour approaches the subjective jitteriness of the last section of GOODFELLAS. While not a groundbreaking masterpiece, it is still full of delights -- for instance, I can't get the image of Dylan and a drunk Johnny Cash warbling a slowed-down version of \\"I'm So Lonesome I Could Cry\\" out of my head.

B000002UAX|3.0|Yes, I am editing my White Album review YET AGAIN. Why? For two reasons: I have no life, and I recently listened to the entire album again. As a result, my opinion on several songs have changed. This is probably the reason why not the Beatles, but the Rolling Stones, are my favorite band. Had The White Album been cut down to one disc as George Martin wanted, the Beatles would probably be my favorite band and the White Album would've probably been their best.<br />I love doing the song-by-song rating thing, so here we go...<br />Back in the USSR: 10/10. Funnier than anything Weird Al Yankovich (AKA Ultimate Novelty #1) ever parodied, the Beatles take jabs at the Beach Boys, Ray Charles and Chuck Berry. Very good way to open the album up.<br />Dear Prudence: 7.5/10. High on most fan's lists, I like it but don't love it. It is an interesting, trippy/folksy tune though.<br />Glass Onion: 9/10. I don't see why so many people hate this song. It's funny and has a nice arrangement. Not a big statement along the lines of A Day in the Life or While My Guitar Gently Weeps (also on this album), but I still like it!<br />Ob-La-Di, Ob-La-Da: 10/10. One of the better moments, and a minor hit single. The ska-influenced song is good fun like other songs here, but the sessions for the song itself caused a lot of tension between John and Paul. In fact, that famous intro (with the slamming of the piano) was a sign of John's frustration.<br />Wild Honey Pie: 1/10. AACK! This is the kind of song we'd expect to show up on bootlegs, not an official release. Arguably the worst song on a Beatle album.<br />The Continuing Story of Bungalow Bill: 1/10. This one's a contender for that title too, though. I don't see what so many other fans see in it... it's just annoying and has that stupid chorus...<br />While My Guitar Gently Weeps: 10/10. The second-best song on this album, composed by George Harrison and featuring Eric Clapton on guitar. Probably George's best composition with the Beatles.<br />Happiness Is a Warm Gun: 10/10. Best song on the album. In it's three minutes or so, it goes through five different movements, the most famous being the screwed-up doowap parody part. Very good!<br />Martha My Dear: 7.5/10. A bit overdone in arrangement perhaps, but great piano.<br />I'm So Tired: 7.5/10. A throwaway, but in a good sense of the word. The Beatles still had a sense of humor, and this song is proof.<br />Blackbird: 8/10. Not a kid's song as some think, but a pro-Civil Rights Movement anthem. I like it!<br />Piggies: 7.5/10. One of the stranger songs in the Beatles catalouge, and one of Harrison's many social commentaries. Along with several other songs on this album, it was sadly misinterperated by the insane Charles Manson.<br />Rocky Raccoon: 10/10. The best damn Western murder ballad around, plain and simple.<br />Don't Pass Me By: 2/10. Another example of how bad this album  could get sometimes. And there are several. Trust me.<br />Why Don't We Do It In the Road: 7/10. One big innuendo. It's utterly stupid, but lots of fun. Led Zeppelin would later make a career singing songs only slightly more complicated lyricially than this. (I think \\"Why don't we do it in the bed\\" would be a good title for most of Zep's songs, but that's off-topic).<br />I Will: 4.5/10. A bore.<br />Julia: 7/10. Good, but so soft you can barely hear it. I don't mind quieter songs, but I prefer to actually hear the songs I'm listening to - a major problem with Julia.<br />Birthday: 10/10. Another one of the Beatles greatest songs, and probably the most famous on this album - you hear it at every baseball game when they read off people's birthdays, and it's often played on the radio in the same way. For some reason, it's been left off all Beatles compilations. Shame on them!!<br />Yer Blues: 10/10. A blooze parody exaggerated so badly that it's hilarious, and has some great blues guitar from the boys. It's interesting that two genres of music (emo and death-metal) were bornfrom the line \\"Yes I'm loney/I wanna die\\". And I don't mean that in a good way.<br />Mother Nature's Son: 5.5/10. Another one of the more boring moments on the album.<br />Everybody's Got Something to Hide Except For Me And My Monkey: 10/10. How can you NOT love this song? Whenever I hear it, I jump up and down like an idiot, screaming. It's great!!!!!! And the title's hilarious!<br />Sexy Sadie: 8/10. The song about Mahareshi Mayatomi (or something like that) Yogi's alledged... well, because it's a family website, let's just say \\"unwanted relations\\" with Mia Farrow on the Beatles' disastirous retreat to India, and it's got nice piano. Originally titled \\"F$^% a Duck\\".<br />Helter Skelter: 10/10. The world's first metal song is right here! Listen closely and you can hear out-of-tune tenor sax and trumpet, played by Lennon and Mal Evans, respectively (neither of them could play either instrument). Total, head-banging chaos, ending with that famous \\"I'VE GOT BLISTERS ON MY FINGERS!\\" scream. Sadly misinterperated by Charles Manson. Now where's the legendary, still unreleased 27-minute outtake?<br />Long Long Long: 5.5/10. Other than the ending it's not really much. Led Zeppelin would later borrow the idea of using a flute on Stairway to Heaven.<br />Revolution 1: 10/10. Underrated, and ripe for rediscovery. I perfer the original of course, but there's nothing wrong with this one!<br />Honey Pie: 2.5/10. Another crappy attempt at '20's jazz by a pop group. Paul may \\"like this kind of music\\", but coming from the Beatles, I don't.<br />Savoy Truffle: 10/10. Ridiculous, stupid, irresistable, and one of the underrated White Album songs.<br />Cry Baby Cry: 5/10. Don't think much of it.<br />Revolution 9: WTF?/10. Whoa, John and Yoko really got away with murder here. Eight minutes of chaos, disorder, mayhem, disarray...yeah. Not a song, but it is a pain to the ears. I swear never to listen to it again.<br />Good Night: 1/10. John said he wanted it \\"Really cheesy\\" and he got it. Sadly, the song itself's a bore.<br />It's a mediocre double-album that coulda been a great single-album, but wasn't. That's what stardom (and drugs) do to you, I guess. (having experienced neither I can't tell for sure).  Thankfully, they would bull it all together for Abbey Road, the Best Album of All Time, then sadly split.<br />Recommended Beatles Albums:<br />Abbey Road<br />Revolver<br />Rubber Soul<br />Sgt. Pepper's Lonely Hearts Club Band<br />A Hard Day's Night<br />Let It Bey.  Mother Nature's Son: 5.5/10. Another one of the more boring moments on the album.  Everybody's Got Something to Hide Except For Me And My Monkey: 10/10. How can you NOT love this song? Whenever I hear it, I jump up and down like an idiot, screaming. It's great!!!!!! And the title's hilarious!  Sexy Sadie: 8/10. The song about Mahareshi Mayatomi (or something like that) Yogi's alledged... well, because it's a family website, let's just say \\"unwanted relations\\" with Mia Farrow on the Beatles' disastirous retreat to India, and it's got nice piano. Originally titled \\"F$^% a Duck\\".  Helter Skelter: 10/10. The world's first metal song is right here! Listen closely and you can hear out-of-tune tenor sax and trumpet, played by Lennon and Mal Evans, respectively (neither of them could play either instrument). Total, head-banging chaos, ending with that famous \\"I'VE GOT BLISTERS ON MY FINGERS!\\" scream. Sadly misinterperated by Charles Manson. Now where's the legendary, still unreleased 27-minute outtake?  Long Long Long: 5.5/10. Other than the ending it's not really much. Led Zeppelin would later borrow the idea of using a flute on Stairway to Heaven.  Revolution 1: 10/10. Underrated, and ripe for rediscovery. I perfer the original of course, but there's nothing wrong with this one!  Honey Pie: 2.5/10. Another crappy attempt at '20's jazz by a pop group. Paul may \\"like this kind of music\\", but coming from the Beatles, I don't.  Savoy Truffle: 10/10. Ridiculous, stupid, irresistable, and one of the underrated White Album songs.  Cry Baby Cry: 5/10. Don't think much of it.  Revolution 9: WTF?/10. Whoa, John and Yoko really got away with murder here. Eight minutes of chaos, disorder, mayhem, disarray...yeah. Not a song, but it is a pain to the ears. I swear never to listen to it again.  Good Night: 1/10. John said he wanted it \\"Really cheesy\\" and he got it. Sadly, the song itself's a bore.   It's a mediocre double-album that coulda been a great single-album, but wasn't. That's what stardom (and drugs) do to you, I guess. (having experienced neither I can't tell for sure).  Thankfully, they would bull it all together for Abbey Road, the Best Album of All Time, then sadly split.   Recommended Beatles Albums:  Abbey Road  Revolver  Rubber Soul  Sgt. Pepper's Lonely Hearts Club Band  A Hard Day's Night   Let It Be

B000A0GP4K|5.0|The problem with viewing a documentary about Dylan is that there is a wealth of material that has been released over the years and they fear is that there will be nothing new.  That was the main complaint about the A&E \\"Biography\\" released a couple of years ago.  It was superficial and not worth the effort.  Sort of like a thumbnail sketch of a great artist.  \\"No Direction Home\\" by Martin Scorcese is a landmark event in portraying the most important artist of our time.  Not only does the film confine itself to a specific 5-6 year period (1961-1966) in Dylan's life, the great one actually participates in the production.  The key question that Scorcese seems to ask over and over is:  how did Dylan go from Woody Guthrie to completely transforming American music in 5 short years.  Most artists struggle their whole lives within a certain genre and are never able to break through to the essence of the form in which they toil.  Dylan is the Shakespeare of our time, and this film makes it abundantly clear that the artistic process was filled with traps, lies, backstabbing, etc.  Scorcese incorporates never before seen and heard recordings, film, interviews, rememberances, and comments by the master himself.  My first viewing of this film yeilded some interesting results.  Dylan is a very funny guy.  He can tell a joke with just his eyes and to watch him spar with reporters and other \\"Mr. Jones'\\" is tremendously entertaining.  No wonder this guy didn't care much for the press.  Dylan also offers a few gems during his interview.  My favorite is \\"You can't be wise and in love at the same time\\".  Upon a second viewing, you definately get the sense that Dylan put up with a whole lot more than most people would have just to practice his art.  Dylan looked weary on the 1966 tour, burned out, despartely tyring to maintain his sanity, while he is \\"just trying to get home\\".  The added material on the DVD don't really add a whole lot to the presentation but some of the extra's are fun.  The film is genius.  It certainly validates Dylan when he decided to only work with the best throughout the years.  Scorcese really catures the times, the artist, the madness, and the crash.  I absolutely loved it and plan on viewing it whole for the third time within a week of its release. <br />

0786715103|4.0|General Romeo Dallaire's \\"Shake Hands with the Devil\\" is an eye-opening book for anyone not familiar with the 1994 genocide in Rwanda.  This book is General Dallaire's personal memoir of his year in Rwanda in command of UNAMIR - the United Nations Assistance Mission for Rwanda.  Despite General Dallaire's and his soldiers' bests efforts, almost a million Rwandans were brutally massacred in the midst of a civil war. <br /> <br />General Dallaire, a francophone Canadian, spent a long and distinguished career in the Canadian Army before being selected to lead UNAMIR.  Reading the guest foreword and then Dallaire's introduction, I expected this book to be full of vitriol and uncontrolled emotions.  Countless times in the beginning I read about General Dallaire's post-traumatic stress disorder.  Fortunately, General Dallaire didn't let his emotions overpower his writing, and his narrative of the year is level and even-handed, even when describing shocking events.  <br /> <br />General Dallaire describes his planning for the mission, his interactions with the UN, and his struggle to understand the political realities of Rwanda as he tries to implement the Arusha Peace Agreement.  When he meets some of the leaders who will soon lead the genocide, he didn't know at that time that he was \\"shaking hands with the devil.\\"  Soon, General Dallaire's tiny UNAMIR tried in vain to at least slow the wanton killings as Rwanda descended in to civil war.  He personally knew most of the major personalities on both sides of the conflict and in the international community, and his personal meetings and communications with these people serve as good personal snapshots of these people. <br /> <br />One thing that struck me was the sheer futility of the mission as General Dallaire's UN forces were extremely short on supplies and manpower - and the UN was unwilling to supply more of either.  At times during the book I admired Dallaire for still trying to stop some of the killing, and at timesI lamented the futility of the mission as Dallaire described another horrific scene of carnage and killing.  Few people would have had the strength to continue to fight for more resources from the UN when it was clear that there was no political will in the world community to support UNAMIR.  After reading this book, I realize that the entire UN concept of these operations - going in with a mix of poorly-equipped troops, no guarantee of logistical support, a UN bureaucracy that prevented even the simplest things to be handled (Dallaire and his staff once had to pay their own landing fee at an airport), and a complete lack of decisive force - is flawed. <br /> <br />There are still a few criticisms of the book.  One is that Dallaire's conclusions are not supported by the rest of his story.  He primarily blames the French and Americans for his problems in Rwanda and gives the UN bureaucracy a pass.  His story vividly describes how the French contributed to the problems in Rwanda, but, other than some second-hand comments about Security Council wranglings, he didn't describe how the Americans bore much of  the blame for the failure of his mission.  (That is not to say that America was blameless in our actions and inactions in Rwanda, when we easily could have stopped the killings.)  He also doesn't resolve the story very well.  After reading a detailed account of one traumatic year in his life, I wanted to know more about the personal and professional problems that he openly admitted to in his introduction.  I also wanted to know more about what happened in Rwanda and to the Rwandan genocidaires.  And finally, in his conclusion, Dallaire links the poverty of the Third World to the 9-11 hijackers, despite the fact that most of the 9-11 hijackers were educated and affluent, not poor and starving African refugees.  <br /> <br />Two other minor complaints: the binding of the paperback is not strong enough to hold together a 600-page book and began to split, and the formatof the glossary made it difficult to use. <br /> <br />Despite these minor flaws, this is a great book and should be read by anyone to get a better understanding of what happened in this forgotten country in the 1990s.  General Dallaire should be commended for working to save these people and for finally telling his story years later.
B000AXSN5G|4.0|Let me first say that I HATE Neil Young's music. Neil leaving CSN&Y was the worst career move that I can think of. I think that his voice sounds like a naked man sitting on a block of ice in a snow storm. Wavery, Shaky, and just plain weird. I think that his hard rocking stuff and lead guitar playing are terrible. He gets the WORST sound out of his Les Paul- worse than anyone I've ever heard (note to Neil- QUIT using the Bigsby Tremelo on your solos!). <br /> <br />Having gotten that off my chest, I happened to listen to this album on Neil's web site before I purchased it for a family member as a gift. He loves Neil... <br /> <br />I was totally surprised. This is a really, really GOOD album. The songs seem heartfelt and more than just 'cranky' as Neil sometimes hits me. Acoustic, Bluesy, Countrified, and (for the most part) well-crafted lyrics make this a great, moody album. Neil reflects on life, family, politics a bit too. It's a lot more stripped down than most of the stuff I've heard from Neil. The absence of his electric guitar playing are worth the price of admission. I happened to read Neil's interview in Time magazine regarding his family, mortality, and music and was very surprised that the guy I was reading about was Neil Young. He's got a lot more depth than just being a cranky old rocker dude. My mistake. The song for his kids is really touching. <br />This album is a good one. Buy it.

0393035158|4.0|Many graduate students reach a point in their education when they realize that they know a lot of things, and they want to share those things with a lot of people.  The result is usually a long, rambling doctoral dissertation, but sometimes it takes the form of something extraordinary, as in the case of Albert Einstein. <br /> <br />Sam Harris is no Einstein, but he is a graduate student with a lot on his mind.  His books tackles the issue of religious faith, as it relates to politics, science, history, and philosophy.  Now, no one is an expert on all these subjects, and one can sense at times that the author is rambling and/or speculating about things he doesn't understand too well.  A few examples are a passing suggestion that ESP should be studied more thoroughly (this has been done many times; no such thing as ESP), a fairly dopey pro-torture argument that would make W's lawyers proud, and a very long discussion of mysticism towards the end of the book. <br /> <br />That said, the writing style is very engaging, and the sheer exuberance with which Harris presents his central thesis makes the book a worthy purchase.  His argument in a nutshell is that faith is a type of human weakness that has historically brought out the worst in people, from The Inquisition to modern terrorism.  It also brings out positive aspects of human nature, but these can be and generally are accessible to reason and rational discourse, with no religious mythologizing necessary.  Harris is right on both counts, and if there's anyone left on Earth who's still on the fence about this issue they should pick up a copy of his book immediately.

1400049628|3.0|I had great hope with this book. I mean, just take a look at the cover and title. On top of that, what a great idea for a book on a cool subject. But after getting through the first half of the book, it just started getting grueling (not in a good way) to read. It just got boring and dragged on. Pretty much this is not a book you read in a couple of settings. You pretty much just thumb through chapters (order of the chapters doesn't matter) when you have the time. 0553212621|5.0|I read Lady Chatterly's lover for the first time in high school, and to be honest, it was more for the juicy bits than anything else. Five years later, though, it was an aside from a professor during a  lecture on Nabokov that convinced me to pick it up again.<br /><br />This was the first novel that I'd read where I truly felt an inner conflict brewing - but in a good way. Lady Chatterly's Lover, though banned for its immorality on its publication, is a book that will force a person to question their own morality and moral judgements, and perhaps rethink them.<br /><br />It is a story of a young woman married to an older man who is confined to a wheel chair due to a war wound. Her husband and she have a respectful relationship, though she does not love him, and though he may love her, he is not particularly attentive. To cure her boredom and satisfy her libido, she turns to adultery. Her first lover is a egotistical Irish writer, but she leaves him quickly over \\"performance\\" issues. She finds herself attracted to Oliver, the gamekeeper on her husband's estate. They continue the affair under the nose of her husband, who, afraid that she will leave him, pretends not to notice.<br /><br />Lawrence's writing is sublime, to say the least. His descriptions  of the estate are picture perfect, and each scene is told almost cinematically. The characters are perfectly developed; you can feel Lady Chatterly's inner turmoil in the beginning of the novel as she copes with caring for her husband and her unsatisfied libido, without any social outlets but her husband's friends. As she begins her affair with Oliver, you notice how that tension that she held is slowly released - and how her husband, paralyzed and coping with a wife who spends less and less time with him, absorbs this tension. Beautiful read.
B0007TKNL0|4.0|I admit, I'll never be a major Phantom \\"fangirl.\\" However, I can understand the appeal of this deeply melodramatic, gothic musical. I'd seen the musical on stage years ago, and while I thought it was very good, it did not inspire a life-long fandom in me. However, the film offers something a stage production cannot--a more close, intimate, and lush experience. So it's no surprise that the movie adaptation had a greater impact on me than the stage musical.<br /><br />I came into this movie with an open mind about casting and other details. I didn't have a firm, rigid idea of who would (or would not) be good as the Phantom. I'd never seen Michael Crawford play the part, only the younger, more attractive Davis Gaines. So, I had no trouble with Gerard Butler as the Phantom. His voice is not perfect, but he sings with great emotion and gusto. It seemed to me that he made the most of his limited vocal skills, and so I found his singing surprisingly good--in a raw, uneven sort of way. Butler is also strikingly handsome in this film, which is funny, because in the few other films I've seen him in, he was more average-looking. I think he's one of these \\"chameleon\\" type guys who can look drastically different in various roles. He sure makes a fabulous impression as the Phantom.<br /><br />Emmy Rossum is lovely, has an absolutely stunning (STUNNING) voice, and seems to possess the right amount of sweetness and innocence for the role of Christine. Patrick Wilson also has a gorgeous voice, (but I *hated* his hair). He does the best he can as the almost universally disliked Raoul. (Well, we don't *dislike* him, we just don't *like* him all that much. He's not nearly as interesting as the Phantom!) Minnie Driver is also great as a prima donna pain-in-the-neck diva. She always has outlandish constumes and is very funny.<br /><br />I enjoyed the music--the melodies are appealing and stick in your head, but after a while I started to think, \\"Didn't I hear this tune before?\\" Lots of recycling of material. It's not all *that* bad, and I liked the music enough to buy a few songs online, but when I compare it to some other famous musicals of the past, it does not measure up.<br /><br />The thing I most enjoyed about this movie are the visual elements--the photography, the costumes, the sets, (oh my, the elaborate sets!). The attention to detail was fantastic. A feast for the eyes. And yeah, the actors and actresses are all a feast for the eyes too--everyone's very attractive.<br /><br />The story is . . . let's not mince words . . . a trifle *thin*. I wished there was more character development, and I wish there was more backstory, more fleshing out of the Phantom's and Christine's prior (and very strange) mentor/protegee relationship. It's still an interesting tale, especially near the ending, when things really start to pick up.<br /><br />My advice to anyone who has never seen any variation of \\"Phantom\\" is to realize that it is *WAY* over-the-top with melodrama--is angst-ridden, gothic, terribly romantic. There's the dramatic swishing of flowing capes, single red roses dropped in the snow, swooning, and so forth. Which makes it a lot of fun to watch, as long as you are willing to be carried along with it.'s not all *that* bad, and I liked the music enough to buy a few songs online, but when I compare it to some other famous musicals of the past, it does not measure up.     The thing I most enjoyed about this movie are the visual elements--the photography, the costumes, the sets, (oh my, the elaborate sets!). The attention to detail was fantastic. A feast for the eyes. And yeah, the actors and actresses are all a feast for the eyes too--everyone's very attractive.    The story is . . . let's not mince words . . . a trifle *thin*. I wished there was more character development, and I wish there was more backstory, more fleshing out of the Phantom's and Christine's prior (and very strange) mentor/protegee relationship. It's still an interesting tale, especially near the ending, when things really start to pick up.    My advice to anyone who has never seen any variation of \\"Phantom\\" is to realize that it is *WAY* over-the-top with melodrama--is angst-ridden, gothic, terribly romantic. There's the dramatic swishing of flowing capes, single red roses dropped in the snow, swooning, and so forth. Which makes it a lot of fun to watch, as long as you are willing to be carried along with it.

0064400018|5.0|I admit I am at a loss for words to describe a book that meant so much to me when I was nine and got the boxed-set of all the Little House books for Christmas. I know I leaped into these books and loved every second of reading them. The setting of isolation in a vast northern woods where a family could live off the land in their little log cabin sent my imagination flaring. I read and re-read each chapter in the life story of Laura Ingalls and her sisters and parents, and bulldog Jack, as they lived in Wisconsin at a time when panthers and bears still roamed the wild forests. The most magical parts to this novel were the ones about Christmas and also about family gatherings. Even though people then had less in the way of material things than we do now, they seemed happier and richer in their joy at what they did possess. I think that's a secret to life that has been lost in our own time. Hopefully anyone who has ever wanted to read this novel has gotten the chance. It's that special, in my view.

B000A0GP4K|3.0|I knew next to nothing about Dylan. But why is it that once again a talented artist revered by many has to turn out to be an awful human being? In fact, a comman thief. Stealing someone's record collection is the seventh deadly sin around these parts as far back as I can remember. Someone out there (you know who you are) still has my white vinyl copy of Bela Lugosi's Dead. But to steal someone's song without their permission to further your own career and wallet is a blindfold, cigarette and firing squad offence. It's still a fairly comman thing to happen to this day. The guy he pinched from was wryly avuncular about it in retrospect but I bet at heart it rankled. But what goes around, comes around and very appropriately the offender is called a Judas at the end of the documentary. Actually, the electric stuff sounded alright to me, although the playing of the last song was obviously despondently delivered. If I turned up to see something gentler and had my eardrums assaulted by discordant psychedelia maybe I would have been miffed too. But it sounded okay. <br /> <br />Dylan was different than I expected him to be. With those eyes and that drawl, he rather reminded me of Clint Eastwood. I felt the film was too hard on journalists. It's not easy to ask questions about music and some people at least tried to ask something thoughtful, even if it didn't come across that way. Unless it was a contractual obligation, Dylan was big enough by then not to have to do press conferences. <br /> <br />One thing Dylan did get right was in not inviting Joan Baez back on stage with him down the line. It was obvious by the cringe making footage that their two vocal styles were too at odds with each other to come together successfully. But some obsessive out there will probably do a five hour documentary proving just how wrong I am on that point. Wasn't that little girl who sung in the beatnik cafe great, though? Something Maulder. Looked a bit like Cher. <br /> <br />Was Like a Rolling Stone the most important song of all time? Well, it's certainly catchy and if it's catchy then who cares about the lyrics?

B000A0GP4K|5.0|No one has mentioned this about the film - it really struck me that Dylan's writing seemed to be truly inspired, almost in a spiritual way.  His long, wordy songs seemed to \\"channel the collective unconscious\\" as someone said - he seemed to be receiving messages from the people, or from the cosmos, or both.  The scenes of him singing at the Newcastle gig made him look transcendent (or high - but if he was, he still managed to nail the songs, and that is a lot to remember.)  I got the feeling that somehow these songs came through him in a way that was beyond his own control.  Sure he was a person who cared about his reputation, but don't overlook, minimize or misunderstand (as some reviewers here have) the brilliance of the songwriting - the poetry - which first changed and then became part of our culture.  The movie is incredibly interesting at a psychological and spiritual level.

0786886811|3.0|Boy, is this book confusing. As many have stated in reviews of the hardback version, the ingredients amounts are off, sometimes waaaay off. I was hoping these errors would have been corrected in this new 2005 paperback version -- but no.<br /><br />Just out of curiosity after receiving the book, I went to Nigella's official website and looked at three of the recipes from this book reprinted on the site. When you click on the American equivalent the ingredient amounts shown there differ -- sometimes dramatically enough to guarantee disaster -- from the printed book (U.S. version) in all three recipes. For instance, the Chocolate Cherry Cupcakes: in the printed version before me it calls for 1/2 cup sugar; on the website: 3/4 cup of sugar (no wonder a previous reviewer complained they weren't sweet enough). In the book: 1 cup \\"self-rising cake flour\\" (an item that American bakers don't even use -- and this item crops up everywhere in the book!); on the website: 1 cup all-purpose flour + 1 tsp baking powder + 1/4 tsp baking soda. For the icing the book calls for 1/3 cup + 1 TB heavy cream; the website: 1/2 cup.<br /><br />But the scariest discrepancy is in the recipe for Coconut Macaroons. The book: 1/3 cup sugar; website: 1/2 cup. Book: 2 TB ground almonds; website: 1/3 cup. But here's the kicker: Book: 1 cup + 2 TB shredded coconut; website: 3 1/3 cups! That's not even close! Needless to say I now have very little confidence in these recipes.<br /><br />So. Three stars because I like Nigella and her writing, and because the book is very handsome. But I'm returning my copy and ordering the UK version -- I'd rather deal with metric conversions than these appalling mistakes.
